So what's an externality? An externality occurs whenever
the actions of one party

impact another party in a way
for which the first party does not receive the
costs and benefits.

So if my actions
impact you, but I don't bear the cost if
they're negative actions

or their benefits if
they're positive actions, then that's an externality. So any time one party's
actions affect another party,

but the first part
does not receive either the costs or the
benefits of that impact, that's an externality.

Let's start with the
standard theory example, OK? The standard example
we always teach now

It's a classic
negative production externality-- "negative"
because it's bad, "production" because it
comes from the supply side,

"externality" because the costs
are borne by another party, not by the party
